title: The Copernicus Satellite
name: The Copernicus Satellite (OAO-3)
alttext: Photograph of Copernicus satellite in the clean room
descript: Copernicus, or Orbiting Astronomical Observatory 3 (OAO-3) was a collaborative effort between the USA (NASA) and the UK (SERC). The main experiment on board was the Princeton University UV telescope, but it also carried an X-ray astronomy experiment developed by the University College London/Mullard Space Science Laboratory.
features: The three proportional counters were also equipped with a six channel pulse height analyzer for obtaining coarse X-ray spectra. All instruments (X-ray and UV) were co-aligned.
First multi-wavelength NASA mission (UV and X-ray instruments on the same satellite)

instruments.name: University College London X-ray Experiment (UCLXE) telescope
instruments.descript: Two proportional counters (one each of low and high energy) and a channel photomultipier (“channeltron”), each with Wolter type 0 grazing incidence X-ray mirrors.

instruments.name: University College London X-ray Experiment (UCLXE) proportional counter
instruments.descript: The primary X-ray instrument was a proportional counter with collimator and no X-ray optics

instruments.name: Princeton Experiment Package
instruments.descript: An 80 cm diameter UV telescope built by Princeton University under the supervision of Lyman Spitzer

highlights: Discovery of several long period pulsars (e.g. Χ Per)
Discovery of absorption dips in Cyg X-1
Long-term monitoring of pulsars and other bright X-ray binaries
Observed rapid intensity variability from Cen A
archive: The HEASARC hosts the raw data in FITS format from UCLXE.
